title: 108_hr4230
content: The Act titled "Global Anti-Semitism Awareness Act of 2004" is also known as the "Global Anti-Semitism Awareness Act". Congress finds that acts of anti-Semitism have increased globally, including in strong democracies. Specific incidents include Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's anti-Semitic remarks in Malaysia in 2003. In various global incidents from 2003 to 2004, anti-Semitic attacks occurred in different countries, including bombings in Istanbul, Turkey, poisoning of anti-Semitic slogans in Hobart, Australia, vandalism in St. Petersburg, Russia, and attacks on Jewish sites in Toronto, Canada. In Toulon, France, on March 23, 2004, a Jewish synagogue and community center were set on fire. Anti-Semitism has manifested through vilification of Zionism and incitement against Israel, with increasing emanation from the Arab and Muslim world, including state-run television in Egypt broadcasting anti-Semitic content. The rise in anti-Semitic violence has led to international organizations like the OSCE focusing on the issue, including conferences dedicated to combating anti-Semitism. Arab television has aired anti-Semitic series promoting conspiracy theories against Jewish people. The OSCE will convene a conference in Berlin to address anti-Semitism, with the US delegation led by Ed Koch. The US supports efforts to combat anti-Semitism through bilateral relationships and interactions with international organizations. Congress has passed resolutions expressing concern about the rise in anti-Semitic violence in Europe. The Sense of Congress is expressed regarding efforts to combat anti-Semitism through bilateral relationships and interactions with international organizations. The Sense of Congress emphasizes the need for continued support in combating anti-Semitism globally through various measures, including advocating for the appointment of a High Commissioner on anti-Semitism, introducing a measure condemning anti-Semitism at the United Nations, establishing a permanent office in the Department of State to monitor and combat anti-Semitism, and documenting acts of anti-Semitism. The Sense of Congress highlights the importance of combating global anti-Semitism by advocating for various measures, including appointing a High Commissioner on anti-Semitism, condemning anti-Semitism at the United Nations, establishing a permanent office in the Department of State to monitor and combat anti-Semitism, and documenting acts of anti-Semitism worldwide. SEC. 4. Authorization for establishment of office to monitor and combat anti-Semitism. The State Department Basic Authorities Act of 1956 is amended to add a new section for monitoring and combating anti-Semitism. The State Department is authorized to establish an Office to Monitor and Combat anti-Semitism, responsible for monitoring and combating acts of anti-Semitism in foreign countries. The Office will be headed by the Director for Monitoring and Combatting anti-Semitism appointed by the Secretary of State. The Office to Monitor and Combat anti-Semitism is responsible for summarizing acts of anti-Semitism and anti-Semitic incitement globally for inclusion in annual reports on human rights practices and international religious freedom. The Director of the Office consults with domestic and international organizations. The Director of the Office may consult with various organizations to fulfill the purposes of the section and may hold public hearings to receive evidence. SEC. 5. INCLUSION IN DEPARTMENT OF STATE ANNUAL REPORTS OF INFORMATION CONCERNING ACTS OF ANTI-SEMITISM IN FOREIGN COUNTRIES. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include a summary of acts of anti-Semitism and anti-Semitic incitement in foreign countries, such as physical violence, harassment, vandalism of Jewish institutions, propaganda promoting racial hatred, and inciting violence against Jewish people. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include a summary of acts of anti-Semitism and anti-Semitic incitement in foreign countries, focusing on violence, harassment, vandalism of Jewish institutions, propaganda promoting racial hatred, and inciting violence against Jewish people. This includes actions taken by governments to respond to such violence, enact and enforce laws protecting religious freedom, and promote anti-bias education. The International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 is amended to include an assessment of acts of anti-Semitism in foreign countries, such as physical violence, harassment of Jewish people, and vandalism of Jewish institutions. The International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 is amended to include an assessment of anti-Semitic acts in foreign countries, including violence, harassment, and vandalism of Jewish institutions. This assessment covers incidents in community institutions like schools, synagogues, and cemeteries, propaganda promoting racial hatred, government responses to violence, and enforcement of laws against such actions. The International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 is amended to include assessing anti-Semitic acts in foreign countries, such as violence, harassment, and vandalism of Jewish institutions. This assessment covers incidents in community institutions like schools, synagogues, and cemeteries, propaganda promoting racial hatred, government responses to violence, and enforcement of laws against such actions. Additionally, the amendments focus on governments enacting and enforcing laws to protect the religious freedom of Jewish people and promoting anti-bias and tolerance education. The effective date of these amendments is one year after the enactment of the Act.
